info.game_comments:
2001 International Championship semifinal game 3.
  From the Las Vegas Hilton.

(1, 1).clue: Explorer "of Arabia" who wrote "Seven Pillars of Wisdom"

(2, 1).clue: An advanced kit for making this at home includes bittering & aromatic hops & specialized dry yeast

(3, 1).clue: Chaim Weizmann was elected this country's first president Feb. 14, 1949

(4, 1).clue: Mick Jagger & this group have had a satisfying career with hits like "Satisfaction" & "Jumpin' Jack Flash"

(5, 1).clue: This country on the Mediterranean coast of France is about 3 times the size of the Mall in Washington, D.C.

(1, 2).clue: Moses Isegawa's 2000 novel "Abyssinian Chronicles" is set partly in Kampala in this, his native country

(2, 2).clue: This often-collected item can mean the body of a handwritten letter, as well as a celebrity signature

(3, 2).clue: On Feb. 14, 1962 the OAS formally excluded this Communist nation from participating in any of its activities

(4, 2).clue: This Latin singing sensation sang "Cup of Life" at President George W. Bush's inauguration

(5, 2).clue: This country landlocked by Switzerland & Austria covers only 62 square miles

(6, 2).clue: This reptile's jaws can crack cattle bones

(1, 3).clue: Argentina's Manuel Puig gave us the "Kiss of" this "Woman"; I read about it on the "web"

(2, 3).clue: Many amateur artists use the medium seen here named for its non-oil based pigments

(3, 3).clue: On Valentine's Day 1951 this "sweet" boxer defeated Jake LaMotta for the world middleweight title

(4, 3).clue: In 2000 these gals released "Forever", their first album since "gingery" Geri Halliwell left the group

(5, 3).clue: Smaller than Connecticut, this 4,400-sq.-mi. nation on the Arabian Peninsula gave women the right to vote in 1999

(6, 3).clue: No longer used, the first verse of Germany's national anthem follows "Deutschland" with this phrase meaning "over all"

(1, 4).clue: This author of "Shogun" called himself a "half-Irish Englishman...born in Australia"

(2, 4).clue: This type of music for 2-10 instruments is played in a small hall or, as its name indicates, a room

(3, 4).clue: Feb. 14 is also the feast day of this Catholic saint who developed for the Slavs an alphabet that bears his name

(4, 4).clue: This group with Agnetha & Bjorn came to fame in the '70s after "Waterloo" won the Eurovision song contest

(5, 4).clue: Nestled in the Pyrenees, this tiny principality boasts a literacy rate of 100%

(6, 4).clue: "The Pilgrim's Progress" is an example of this symbolic literary form

(1, 5).clue: Former first lady Jehan Sadat called her moving memoir "A Woman of" this country

(3, 5).clue: Valentine's Day events in this U.S. city include a 1929 massacre & the 1920 founding of the League of Women Voters

(4, 5).clue: It was "smooth" sailing for this guitar great who released his award-winning "Supernatural" album in 1999

(5, 5).clue: The Sammarinese are the people of this serene republic that covers a whopping 23 square miles

(6, 5).clue: This adjective means formed by sand, silt or mud left by flowing water, like a plain or a deposit

(1, 1).clue: The city now known as Volgograd was once named for him

(2, 1).clue: Take me out to the futbol game at Estadio Azteca in this capital city

(4, 1).clue: In Paris, France I'll spring for a trip to this department store whose name is French for "spring"

(5, 1).clue: In describing the effect of global warming, the Earth is often compared to this structure seen here

(6, 1).clue: This type of ring means you & your beloved are hitched, you've tied the knot

(1, 2).clue: From 1951 to 1960 this African dictator was the heavyweight champion of his country

(2, 2).clue: Take me out with the crowd at this "religious" London cricket ground, HQ of the Marylebone Cricket Club

(4, 2).clue: You can see a Vegas-style show (with showgirls!) at this Parisian nightspot whose name means "red windmill"

(5, 2).clue: Chemist Svante Arrhenius of this country was concerned about global warming 100 years ago

(1, 3).clue: He's the European dictator seen here in 1936

(2, 3).clue: Buy me some sushi & miso soup at the all-Japan demonstration of this form of fencing

(4, 3).clue: Mais Oui!  The original version of this monument is in France, but the one seen here belongs to Paris Las Vegas

(5, 3).clue: The U.S. & E.U. were represented at a December 1997 global warming summit in this Asian city

(1, 4).clue: Cuba's leader 1952-1959, his former presidential palace now houses Havana's Museum of the Revolution

(2, 4).clue: I don't care if I never get back from Bulgarska Armia Stadium in this city -- actually, I would prefer to get back

(3, 4).clue: His 1974 bestseller "Jaws" led to a new interest in & a new respect for sharks as well

(4, 4).clue: To be more like France, Las Vegas needs a tour of les egouts, which are these (& don't forget your nose clips!)

(5, 4).clue: It's not so "funny" that this gas, N2O, traps 270 times more heat than carbon dioxide

(6, 4).clue: This type of agency will market your product through radio & TV spots, billboards, etc....

(1, 5).clue: He was the leader of France's Committee of Public Safety in 1793 & 1794

(2, 5).clue: Take me out to the Royal Calcutta Turf Club, with 2 racing seasons: winter & this storm-named one

(3, 5).clue: 3-word title of the 1959 Bobby Darin hit that starts "Oh, the shark, babe, has such teeth, dear"

(4, 5).clue: Parts of the Paris Las Vegas facade resembles this Parisian theatre, the lair of the "Phantom"

(5, 5).clue: CFCs, or chlorofluorocarbons, menace the ozone layer; HFCs, which stand for these, contribute to global warming

(6, 5).clue: Novelist Maxim Gorky apporopriately co-authored a book on "The Art and Craft" of this

(0, 0).clue: It's the town where Francisco Marto, Jacinta Marco & their cousin became famous in 1917
